title: 103_s2479
content: The Act titled "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" aims to promote the construction and operation of US flag cruise vessels. It includes an amendment regarding coastwise transportation of passengers. The Act "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes US flag cruise vessel construction and operation. It includes requirements for vessels transporting passengers in coastwise trade, ownership by US citizens or entities, compliance with Merchant Marine Act, and documentation certification. Title 46, United States Code, allows cruise vessels under a demise charter to operate in coastwise trade with certain conditions and approval from the Secretary. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows cruise vessels to operate in coastwise trade under specific conditions approved by the Secretary, with exceptions for vessels to be reflagged if they meet certain criteria. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows cruise vessels to operate in coastwise trade under specific conditions approved by the Secretary. Vessels over 15 years old can be documented under the chapter if the owner has a contract for a new vessel with at least 80% capacity. This authority terminates 18 months after receiving a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows cruise vessels to operate in coastwise trade under specific conditions approved by the Secretary. The Act includes provisions for the termination of authority if a new vessel is not under construction within 18 months. Additionally, there are limitations on operating vessels between ports served by other cruise vessels in coastwise trade. Coastwise endorsement restricts vessel operation between ports served by other cruise vessels or Hawaii islands. Penalties include a $1,000 civil penalty per passenger transported in violation, vessel seizure, and disqualification from coastwise trade. A construction contract for a cruise vessel requires reaching a certain stage of construction within a specified period to prevent owning or operating vessels in coastwise trade. Coastwise trade includes passenger transportation within the US or via a foreign port, and a cruise vessel must be at least 10,000 gross tons. A cruise vessel must be at least 10,000 gross tons, have accommodations for 200 passengers, and not be a ferry. A "related person" includes holding companies, subsidiaries, affiliates, officers, directors, or agents of the person. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to deem certain vessels compliant with specific regulations and requirements for inspection and certification. Vessels meeting specified criteria are eligible for a certificate of inspection and authorization to engage in coastwise trade. The amendment to Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, allows vessels meeting specific criteria to be authorized for coastwise trade under certain regulations. SEC. 5 amends the Shipping Act, 1916 regarding citizenship for vessel operation in passenger transport. SEC. 6 amends Title XI of the Merchant Marine Act, 1936. AMENDMENT TO TITLE XI OF THE MERCHANT MARINE ACT, 1936: Section 1101(b) is amended to include "passenger, cargo" instead of just "passenger cargo." PERMITS FOR VESSELS ENTERING UNITS OF NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. The Secretary of the Interior has priority rules for operating vessels in National Park System units. Priority is given to vessels documented in the US or Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act, followed by foreign vessels already permitted to operate in the unit. The Secretary of the Interior has the authority to revoke or refuse to renew permission for foreign-documented vessels to operate in National Park System units if there is a request to operate a US-documented vessel in the same unit due to permit limitations. The Secretary of the Interior cannot revoke permits for visitor services in National Park System units for those holding rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. If a permit is revoked, the person has the right of first refusal for a new permit when conditions change, limited to the number of revoked permits.
